title: 114_hr1492
content: The "Child Care Access and Refundability Expansion Act" or "Child CARE Act" includes a credit for dependent care expenses. The Child Care Access and Refundability Expansion Act introduces a refundable credit for dependent care expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Section 21 is redesignated as section 36C, with amendments specifying that the credit does not apply to services provided outside the United States. Conforming amendments are made to sections 23(f)(1) and 35(g)(6) of the Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to redesignate Section 21 as Section 36C, with various amendments to different sections such as 129 and 213. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to redesignate Section 21 as Section 36C, with amendments to various sections such as 129 and 213, including inserting "36C" in multiple sections. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by inserting a new item after section 36B. Section 36C of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to increase the dollar limitation for expenses for household and dependent care services necessary for gainful employment. The credit allowed for qualified expenses is increased to 50 percent, and an income limitation is added to restrict the credit for taxpayers. Inflation Adjustment: For taxable years after 2015, the $8,000 and $200,000 income limits in Section 36C of the Internal Revenue Code will be increased based on the cost-of-living adjustment for that year. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2014, with any increase rounded to the nearest multiple of $100. SEC. 3. CREDIT FOR EDUCATION OF EMPLOYEES OF CHILD CARE CENTERS. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 adds a new section for a Child Care Center Education Credit. The Child Care Center Education Credit allows for a 50% credit on child care educational expenses incurred by the taxpayer for operating a qualified child care center, with a limit of $1,000 per eligible employee. The Child Care Center Education Credit provides a 50% credit on educational expenses for operating a qualified child care center. Eligible employees are those whose primary job is caring for children in a qualified child care center. No double benefit deduction is allowed for expenses used to determine the credit. The Child Care Center Education Credit offers a 50% credit on educational expenses for running a qualified child care center. Eligible employees are those primarily caring for children in the center. The amendment adds the credit to the general business credit under section 38 of the tax code. The Child Care Center Education Credit, offering a 50% credit on educational expenses for qualified child care centers, is added to the general business credit under section 38 of the tax code. The amendments made by this section apply to expenses paid or incurred after the enactment date, in taxable years ending after that date.
